Meigs (1816–1892)|Meigs, Montgomery C.]] | architecture = Second Empire | added = February 26, 1996 | area = {{convert|17.2|acre}} | governing_body = [[U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs]] | mpsub = {{NRHP url|id=64500016|title=Civil War Era National Cemeteries MPS}} | refnum = 96000029<ref name="nris">{{NRISref|2009a}}</ref> }} '''Culpeper National Cemetery''' is a [[U.S. National Cemetery|United States National Cemetery]] located in the town of [[Culpeper, Virginia|Culpeper]], in [[Culpeper County, Virginia]]. Administered by the [[United States Department of Veterans Affairs]], it encompasses {{convert|29.6|acre|m2}} of land, and as 2014, had over 11,000 interments.
== History ==
During the [[American Civil War]], the territory around the city of Culpeper was defended vigorously by both sides, as it was a strategic point almost exactly between [[Washington D.C.]] and the capital of the [[Confederate States of America|Confederacy]], [[Richmond, Virginia]]. Numerous battles took place in the region, including the [[Battle of Cedar Mountain]] and the [[Battle of Chancellorsville]]. The dead from those conflicts were buried nearby in makeshift grave sites. After the war a reburial program was initiated, and in 1867, Culpeper National Cemetery was established to reinter many of the remains from the makeshift sites.<ref name=vacem>{{Citation | title = Cemeteries - Culpeper National Cemetery | newspaper = [[United States Department of Veterans Affairs]] | date = 2010-01-08 | url = http://www.cem.va.gov/cems/nchp/culpeper.asp | accessdate = 2010-06-30}} </ref>
The original cemetery comprised {{convert|6|acre}}, bought from Edward B. Hill of Culpeper for [[United States dollar|$]]1,400. The original [[Second Empire (architecture)|Second Empire Victorian]] caretakers lodge was built in 1872 and was designed by [[Montgomery C. Meigs (1816–1892)|Montgomery C. Meigs]]. Many improvements to the grounds and facilities at the cemetery were made during the 1930s as part of the [[New Deal]]. These [[Make-work job|make-work]] improvements included replacing the original 1870s tool house at the cost of $8,000 in 1934, raising and realigning 912 headstones in May 1934, by the [[Civil Works Administration]], and realignment and re-setting 402 headstones in 1936 though a [[Works Project Administration]] project.<ref name=vacem/>
Having operated without any major improvements since the 1930s, the cemetery was closed to new interments on November 17, 1972. On September 1, 1973, administration of the cemetery was transferred from the U.S. Army to the [[United States Department of Veterans Affairs|Veterans Administration’s]] new [[United States National Cemetery|National Cemetery System]] created by the National Cemetery Act of 1973. In 1975 another {{convert|10.5|acre|m2}} was donated by the [[Veterans of Foreign Wars]], Burton-Hammond Post 2524,<ref name=vacem/> and in 2001 another plot of {{convert|12.3|acre|m2}} was purchased, which has been developed for future interments. The cemetery was reopened to interments on January 16, 1978.<ref name=vacem/>
Culpeper National Cemetery was listed in the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 1996.<ref name=vacem/> It is included in the [[South East Street Historic District]].
== Notable monuments == * The states of Maine, Massachusetts, New York, Ohio, and Pennsylvania have erected markers dedicated to regiments from those states who had members die in the [[Battle of Cedar Mountain]]. ** The Maine monument is of granite construction and is dedicated to the 22 officers and soldiers from the 10th Maine Volunteer Infantry who died at Cedar Mountain.<ref name=vacempdf>{{Citation | title = Culpeper National Cemetery | newspaper = [[United States Department of Veterans Affairs]] | date = 2001-07-05 | url = http://www.cem.va.gov/pdf/culpeper.pdf | accessdate = 2010-06-30}}</ref> ** The Massachusetts monument was erected by members of the 2nd Massachusetts Infantry in 1893.<ref name=vacem/> ** The New York monument was erected in 1902 to honor the members of the 28th New York Volunteer Infantry, 1st Brigade, 1st Division, 12th Corps, Army Corps of the Potomac who died at Cedar Mountain.<ref name=vacem/> ** The Ohio monument is of granite and bronze construction and was erected by the 7th Ohio Regimental Association.<ref name=vacempdf/> ** The Pennsylvania monument was erected in 1910.<ref name=vacem/> * The Armed Forces Monument was erected November 1992 and was sponsored by the American Legion Post 330 and Veterans of Foreign Wars Post 2524. The monument was officially dedicated May 28, 2001.<ref name=vacem/> * A memorial to all of the Unknown burials from the Civil War was erected in 1988 by the Veterans of Foreign Wars, Burton-Hammond Post 2524. * The seven and a half feet tall National Military Cemetery monument constructed from a cast iron seacoast [[Rodman gun|artillery tube]].<ref name=vacempdf/>
